comments.body: Just wondering, why? The previous type was more correct in my opinion.

The original change argued that you could stringify anything. #12992 

not sureÂ why you weren't pinged

`undefined` is also a valid value, so we should add `| undefined` here as well. So not sure if these changes actually add anything extra. See [the docs](https://github.com/sindresorhus/query-string#falsy-values).

As far as I see `undefined` isnt a valid value.

On the other hand, current definition does not compile using `strictNullChecks` which is a must have. isnt it?

Yes, for `stringify` `| undefined` must be specified for beeing `strictNullChecks` safe.

This PR focuses solely on `parse`.
Oh sorry, totally missed that. You're right, this is totally correct :).

For `parse()` I was wrong! A `| null` is not needed for using `parse()` and check the return value for having key/value pairs with `null`values.

I recall this PR. Sorry!

P.S.: A `| null` is only neccessary for the implementation of `parse()` if it would be written using TypeScript with strict null checks. But that's not the case.
